title.reg: Drawings for Mary Wollstonecraft's "Original Stories from Real Life"

titlestmt.title: Drawings for Mary Wollstonecraft's "Original Stories from Real Life" : electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 104KB; 20 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 65KB to 305KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and Archives August 2009
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake's ten monochrome wash drawings illustrating Mary Wollstonecraft's Original Stories from Real Life and the first and second editions of the book containing Blake's six engravings of his designs. The designs and inscribed texts in all three series are fully searchable and are supported by our Inote and ImageSizer applications.
In 1788, Joseph Johnson published the first edition of Mary Wollstonecraft's morally instructive narrative for children, Original Stories from Real Life; with Conversations, Calculated to Regulate the Affections, and Form the Mind to Truth and Goodness. A few years later, Johnson decided to issue a new edition, for which he commissioned Blake to prepare a series of illustrations. Blake's extant drawings, now in the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress, are datable to c. 1791. In addition to these ten designs, Blake must have executed at least one further drawing as a preliminary for his fifth plate; this drawing is untraced. Six designs were selected for publication in the 1791 edition of Wollstonecraft's book; Blake engraved the designs himself. The first and second states of Blake's plates appear variously in copies of the 1791 edition. The second edition to contain Blake's plates was published by Johnson in 1796; it contains the third (final) states of Blake's plates. The copy of the 1791 edition now in the Archive is from the Huntington Library; it contains the second states of the plates. The copy of the 1796 edition in the Archive is from the Essick collection and contains the third (final) states of the plates.
Modern interpreters of the illustrations have detected a pictorial critique of Wollstonecraft's stories. Blake appears to have found her morality too calculating, rationalistic, and rigid. He represents Wollstonecraft's spokesperson, Mrs. Mason, as a domineering presence. From Blake's perspective, Mason's acts of charity are excessively condescending and tend to reinforce the underlying social conditions that create disparities between wealth and poverty. As Blake wrote in "The Human Abstract," "Pity would be no more, / If we did not make somebody Poor."
With this publication, the Archive adds a new set of scholarly tools. These tools, known collectively as our Related Works system, are designed to show relationships among works and individual objects in the Archive. They function at two levels. First, work index pages now include active links to related materials in the Archive (for example, a set of preliminary sketches for a group of engravings). Second, the Show Me menu on object view pages now includes Related Works in the Archive. Like the work-level menu, this list includes active links to the related objects and is meant to allow study of the related materials side-by-side. The Wollstonecraft illustrations are the first publication in the Archive to use this feature.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

title.hi: Drawings for Mary Wollstonecraft's "Original Stories from Real Life"

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 10.8 x 6.0 cm. and 14.0 x 6.8 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 11.7 x 6.2 cm. and 14.2 x 6.8 cm.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink with gray and black washesBlake's inscriptions below the designs on Objects 1-3 and 5 are in pencil.
objinfo.watermark: none visibleThe drawings are hinged to backing mats and thus it is very difficult to check for watermarks.

provenance.name: Lessing J. Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress
provenance.dealer: The Rosenbach Company (A. S. W. Rosenbach)
provenance.note: Possibly Joseph Johnson, who commissioned the drawings; acquired at an unknown time by Alexander Gilchrist; Mrs. Alexander Gilchrist, probably by inheritance in 1861; her son, Herbert H. Gilchrist, by gift or by inheritance no later than 1885; H. Buxton Forman, sold from his collection, Anderson Galleries auction, New York, 15 March 1920, lot 65, with five of the engravings and five letters by Herbert H. Gilchrist ($1000 to A. Edward Newton); sold from Newton's collection, Parke-Bernet auction, New York, 16 April 1941, lot 120, with the 5 engravings and 5 letters ($1500 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1946.

objnote.p: This drawing was not selected as one of the six to be engraved. The pencil inscription below the design is in Blake's hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An adult female (Mrs. Mason) stands on a path or road with two female children (Mary and Caroline) to her left and right. They stand just outside a doorway to the right. Mrs. Mason is gowned and wears a large hat. She stands with her arms at her sides and looks towards the child to the right. Her mouth appears to be slightly open and she may be speaking. Both children have long hair, are gowned, and wear wide-brimmed hats. The child to the left faces forward with her head turned to the right and up to look at Mrs. Mason. The child's right arm is pictured at her side. The child to the right is facing left in profile. Her head is up and she also looks towards Mrs. Mason. The child's left arm is bent; she may be touching or holding Mrs. Mason's left arm in her left hand. A large tree rises to the right of the adult figure and two more trees, possibly with a river or lake and a hill behind them, are seen to the left of the figures. Wash above and to the left of the figures suggests a sky with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: An adult female (Mrs. Mason) stands in the center of the design with two children (Mary and Caroline). She is gowned and wears a large hat; her left shoe is visible. There may be a shawl or large scarf over her shoulders, but perhaps this is part of her gown. Her body faces forward with her head turned to the right. She may be looking at the child to the right. Her arms are down at her sides. Her mouth appears to be slightly open and she may be speaking. Her hair may be long, but tucked behind her neck.

To the left of the central figure stands a female child with long hair (either Mary or Caroline). She is gowned and wears a wide-brimmed hat. One shoe (her right?) is visible. She stands facing forward with her right arm at her side and her head turned up and to the right. She is looking at the central figure (Mrs. Mason).

A female child (either Mary or Caroline) stands to the right of the central figure. She is gowned and wears a wide-brimmed hat. One shoe (her left?) is visible. She stands facing left with her head turned up; she is looking at the central figure (Mrs. Mason). The child's left arm is bent upward; she may be touching or holding Mrs. Mason's left arm. The fingers on her left hand appear to be spread.
A building, probably a house, stands on the right. A large doorway and a roof are visible.
The figures appear to stand on a path or road.

The trunk of a large tree rises to the right of the central figure. The leaves of this tree hang over the figures, particularly to the left. In the middle distance to the left of the figures are two more trees. These may be a pine (furthest left) and a cypress.
Washes above and to the left of the figures suggests a sky with clouds.
There may be a body of water, possibly a river or lake, behind the trees on the left. A hill rises further in the distance.

objnote.p: This drawing was not selected as one of the six to be engraved. The pencil inscription below the design is in Blake's hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An adult female (Mrs. Mason) and her two charges (Mary and Caroline) stand on a winding path to the left of a large tree. The tree has clearly visible roots, a large trunk, and leafy branches that arch to the left over the figures' heads. All three figures are gowned and wear hats. Mrs. Mason is the rightmost figure in the group. Her body faces right, but her head is turned back to the left; she looks down towards the children. Her right arm is down at her side while her left arm is bent upward and she points or gestures above. The child furthest to the left is seen in profile facing right. Her long hair may be drawn back into a braid. Her right arm is bent; her left arm is not visible. The middle figure also faces right and has long hair that falls onto her shoulders. She is bending slightly forward. Her right arm is bent with the palm facing out, and her left arm is at her side with the palm facing down. These gestures, and her slightly-opened mouth, suggest surprise. More distant trees (at least six in all) appear to the left and right of the group of figures. Wash above the figures suggests a sky with clouds. Shadows extend from the feet of the figures to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: An adult female (Mrs. Mason) stands to the left of a large tree. She is gowned and wears a large hat; one shoe (the right?) is pictured. Her right arm is down at her side, while her left arm is bent upward as she points or gestures to the tree or sky above. Her body faces to the right, but her head is turned back to the left and she looks down towards the two children. Her hair may be long, but pulled back behind her neck.

A female child (Mary or Caroline) stands to the far left in the group of figures. She is gowned and wears a hat; one shoe (the right?) is pictured. The girl has long hair that may be drawn back into a braid. She faces left in profile. Her right arm is bent and the fingers on her right hand are spread. Her left arm is not visible.

A female child (Mary or Caroline) stands to the left of Mrs. Mason, in the center of the group of figures. She is gowned and wears a hat over her long hair; one shoe (the left?) is pictured. She faces right and is slightly bent forward. Her right arm is bent and her right palm faces out. Her left arm is down at her side with the palm facing down. These gestures, and her facial expression with mouth slightly open, suggest surprise.
The figures stand on a path or road that is also shown in the background of the scene.
Shadows extend along the ground right of the figures' feet.

A large tree with visible roots stands to the right of the group of figures; its leafy branches arch over the figures' heads to the left. Other trees are shown in the background to the left and right of the figures. At least six distinct tree trunks are visible.
Hills or mountains are vaguely suggested on the horizon. Wash above the group of figures suggests a sky with clouds.

desc.objtitle: How Delighted the Old Bird Will Be, Object 3 (Butlin 244.3)

objnote.p: This drawing was not selected as one of the six to be engraved. The pencil inscription below the design is in Blake's hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures stand on a winding path. A gowned female child (Caroline) stands in the foreground facing right. She is bent forward with both knees slightly bent with her arms extended and reaching towards the right. With both hands she holds a small bird's nest. A large bush (or possibly the low branches of a tree) is pictured to the right of the figure. Above her stands a male child wearing a coat, shirt, and pants. His right arm is bent upward with his hand positioned beside (or possibly touching) his head. His left arm is extended and he points to the right. The trunk of a large tree is pictured behind and right of the boy. This tree dominates the top half of the design. To the left of these figures stand two females, an adult (Mrs. Mason, on the right) and child (Mary, on the left). Both figures are gowned and wear hats. The adult appears to be holding the child's upraised left hand. Washes suggest distant trees left and right of these two figures.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower half of the design, a female child (Caroline) stands facing right. She wears a long gown and a hat. She is bent forward at the waist with her legs apart and slightly bent. With both hands she holds a bird's nest. Her arms are bent and extended forward as she replaces the bird's nest in the bush or tree to the right. The shoe on her right foot is pictured.
The female child in the foreground holds a small bird's nest in her hands. A few lines above the nest hint at baby birds.

A male child with long hair stands behind the front-most female figure. He wears a shirt, a long coat, and pants or breeches. His right arm is bent with his hand positioned beside his head (possibly touching or pointing to his head). His left arm is extended and he points towards the right.

A female figure (Mrs. Mason) stands to the left of the male figure. She is gowned and wears a large dark hat. Her face is not pictured, but her head and body are turned slightly to the left, towards the child to her right. She may be looking down toward the child. Her right arm may be at her side, and she appears to hold the child's upraised left hand with her lowered left hand.

A female child (Mary) stands to the left of Mrs. Mason. She is gowned and wears a hat. Her face is not pictured, but she faces right and her head is turned up towards Mrs. Mason. The child's right arm is at her side. Her left arm is bent upward, and she appears to hold the left hand of Mrs. Mason.

The trunk of a large tree grows to the right of the male figure. The indistinct leaves of this tree dominate the top half of the design. A bush or possibly the low branches of another tree are pictured to the right of the central female child. Washes to the left and right of Mrs. Mason suggest distant trees.
The figures stand on a winding path or road. It appears to extend behind the two figures in the middle distance on the left.

desc.objtitle: 'Look What a Fine Morning It Is,' for Plate 1, Object 4 (Butlin 244.4)

objnote.p: The design was engraved as the frontispiece (plate 1) in the book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female, Mrs. Mason, stands between two female children, Mary and Caroline. The adult wears a large hat with a bow, and a sash is tied around her waist. Her long hair rests upon her shoulders. Her arms are raised horizontally over the heads of the other figures, slightly bent at the elbows, palms facing out and fingers spread. Her eyes are cast down as if looking at the ground. The two female children to her left and right are both gowned and wear hats over their long hair. The child on the right has her arms crossed in front of her chest while the child on the left has her arms bent upwards, palms vertical, with the fingers slightly spread. The figures stand in front of a doorway with a large, leafy, and branching vine to the left of the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female, Mrs. Mason, stands facing forward between two female children. She wears a large hat with a bow, and a sash is tied around her waist. We see both her shoes, the right most prominently. Her long hair rests upon her shoulders. Her arms are raised horizontally over the heads of the other figures, slightly bent at the elbows, palms facing out and fingers spread. Her eyes are cast down as if looking at the ground.

A gowned female child stands to the left of the central figure. She is one of Mrs. Mason's charges, either Mary or Caroline. She has long hair and wears a hat and shoes. The hem of her gown is ruffled. She faces forward with her arms bent and raised in front of her. Her palms are held vertically, with the fingers on at least her left hand spread. Her eyes are raised slightly.

A gowned female child stands to the right of the central figure. She is one of Mrs. Mason's charges, either Mary or Caroline. She has long hair and wears a hat and shoes. The hem of her gown is ruffled. She faces forward with her arms crossed over her chest. Her eyes are raised as if looking at the central figure.
Behind the group of figures is a building with a clearly defined door frame.
A branching vine rises to the left of the group of figures. The vine bears large leaves, perhaps ten in all.

desc.objtitle: She Turned Her Eyes on Her Cruel Master, Object 5 (Butlin 244.5)

objnote.p: This drawing was not selected as one of the six to be engraved. The pencil inscription below the design is in Blake's hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A small family occupies a room of a house with the floor, door, a back wall, and supporting beams pictured. A window with a lattice screen or pane design is shown in the upper right corner. Through the doorway we see a fence. Above the fence, dark shapes suggest trees and a lighter wash indicates clouds. A young boy stands to the right of the doorway. He wears a coat, pants or breeches, and tights or stockings. His right arm is bent towards his chest and he appears to hold the front of his coat. To the right, an old woman sits in a chair. She is gowned and wears a cap or bonnet on her head. A blanket or apron is draped across her lap. Her arms are extended with her hands on her knees. Her palms are turned slightly out (towards the viewer) with the fingers on both hands spread. Both figures wear an expression of fear or surprise. The rightmost figure in the scene is a male seated in a chair. He faces left and is seen in profile. He wears a shirt or long coat, pants, and tall boots. The figure's left arm is bent and rests in his lap. He is looking at the female dog to the left. The dog stands in profile facing right, and looks toward the man in the chair. Between them on the ground is the corpse of a small dog; it is one of the female dog's young. The dead dog lies on its side with its legs facing to the left and its head down closest to the viewer.

component.illusobjdesc: A male child or youth stands with his legs spread apart (only his right leg is clearly pictured). He wears a coat, breeches, probably a shirt, and tights or stockings. His right arm is bent toward his chest, and he appears to hold his coat with his right hand. His left arm is not pictured, but there is a slight indication that his left hand rests on the back of the chair to the right. His expression suggests fear or surprise.

To the right of the male child is an old woman sitting in a chair. She is gowned and wears a bonnet. We see her right foot, probably wearing a shoe. An apron or blanket is draped over her lap. Her arms are extended with her hands on her knees. Her palms are turned slightly out (towards the viewer) with the fingers on both hands spread. She wears an expression of fear or surprise.

The rightmost figure in the scene is a male seated in a chair. He faces left and is seen in profile. He wears a shirt or (long?) coat, pants or breeches, and tall boots. A bit of drapery hanging from the chair may be his coat or a blanket. The figure's left arm is bent and rests in his lap. He is looking at the dog to the left. His hair is long.
A female dog stands facing right and looks toward the seated male.

The corpse of a small dog (one of the female dog's young) lies on the floor between the dog and the seated male. The body of the dog appears to lie on its side, with its legs to the left and its head down closest to the viewer.
The old woman and adult male both sit in chairs.
The scene is set in a room of a house with the floor, door, back wall, and supporting ceiling beams pictured. A window with a lattice screen or pane design is shown in the upper right corner.
Through the doorway on the left side of the design we see a fence. Above the fence, dark shapes suggest trees and a lighter wash indicates clouds.

lg.l: She turned her eyes on her

desc.objtitle: 'The Dog Strove to Attract His Attention,' for Plate 2, Object 6 (Butlin 244.6)

objnote.p: The design was engraved as plate 2 in the book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male figure stands in a room with the dead bodies of two children. The man, Robin, is the father of the children, the boy Jacky (closest to the viewer) and the girl Nancy. The adult has short, curly hair and wears breeches and a sleeveless shirt or vest. His body faces forward with his head turned to the right and slightly down; he wears an expression of despair or grief and may be looking at the two children. His muscular arms are down at his sides with both hands forming fists; his bare feet are prominent. Two corpses—a male and female child—lay supine on a bed. Their eyes are closed and their heads are back; their heads seem to be resting on a bundle or pillow. The male child has long curly hair and wears breeches and a shirt. His left arm is pictured at his side with the palm down. The female child is gowned and has long hair. Her left arm is bent and rests on her chest. A slight indication of her left hand suggests that her hands are clasped over her chest. A dog with curly fur stands to the left of the male figure. It stretches upward with its mouth open and tongue extended to lick the man's right fist. Behind the male figure, a large casket or coffin rests on two benches or stools. There is a single window high on the right-most wall.

component.illusobjdesc: A male figure stands in a room with the bodies of two dead children; he is Robin, their father. He has short, curly hair and wears breeches and a sleeveless shirt or vest. His body faces forward with his head turned to the right and slightly down; he wears an expression of despair or grief and he may be looking at the two children. His muscular arms are down at his side with both hands forming fists. His bare feet are prominent.

The corpse of a male child (Jacky, closest to the viewer) lies supine on a bed with his head bent back and his eyes closed. He wears breeches and a shirt. His left arm is pictured at his side with the palm down.

The corpse of a gowned female child (Nancy, second from the viewer) lies supine on a bed with her head bent back and her eyes closed. Her left arm is bent and rests on her chest. Slight indications of her left hand suggest that her hands are clasped and resting on her chest.

A dog with curly fur stands to the right of the male figure. Its hind legs are on the ground or floor, while its front legs stand on the edge of the bed. It stretches upward with its mouth open and tongue extended to lick the man's right fist.
The two dead children lie on a bed, used here as a bier. Their heads are supported by a bundle or pillow.
There is a single window high on the right-most wall.
Behind the male figure, a large casket or coffin rests on two benches or stools.

desc.objtitle: 'Indeed We Are Very Happy,' for Plate 3, Object 7 (Butlin 244.7)

objnote.p: The drawing was cut in half horizontally and the lower half cut vertically from the lower edge to its mid-point; the pieces of paper have been reattached. The design was engraved as plate 3 in the book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female (Mrs. Mason) sits in a chair on the left and faces right. Her long curly hair falls onto her shoulders. Her arms rest in her lap, with her hands on her knees. Her eyes are down and she appears to be smiling; she looks at the two female children (Mary and Caroline) sitting to either side of her. Both children have long hair; the figure on the left has hers drawn back into a braid. The figure on the left is seen from the side, with her upper body turned away from the viewer. Her right hand rests on top of the woman's right hand. Her head is down and rests in the woman's lap in an apparent expression of sorrow. The figure on the right mirrors this position; she holds the woman's left hand with her left hand. To the right of this group, a male figure sits in a chair facing left. He is Jack, a sailor, with two of his children near him. He wears a coat, pants, shoes, and a scarf at his neck. His left arm, and probably his right arm, are bent and rest in his lap. His crutch lies horizontally on the floor below his left foot. A child (possibly female and wearing a hat) stands behind and to the left of the seated man. She has her head down, and holds a scarf or cloth to her face. The figure appears to stand, but her legs are not pictured. A male child stands to the right of the seated male figure. He may be leaning against the back of the chair. He has short curly hair and his eyes are cast down. His arms are crossed in front of his chest, with his left hand holding or resting on his right shoulder. His legs are crossed at the ankles. He wears a shirt and breeches. The six figures appear in a room with a large fireplace. A fire burns on a stack of wood kindling and smoke rises up the chimney. Two model ships sit on a mantel above the fireplace; the ship on the right has sails. Four indistinct objects, possibly candlesticks, stand between the two ships. Two framed pictures hang on the wall to either side of the mantel. The ceiling includes beams.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female (Mrs. Mason) sits in a chair facing right. Her long, curly hair falls onto her shoulders. Her arms rest in her lap, with her hands on her knees. Her eyes are down and she appears to be smiling; she may be looking at the two female children sitting to either side of her.

Two gowned female children, Mary and Caroline, sit to either side of the adult female, Mrs. Mason. Both figures have long hair; the figure on the left has hers drawn back into a braid. The figure on the left is seen from the side, but her upper body is twisted away from the viewer as she bends forward towards the woman. The girl's right arm rests in the woman's lap; her right hand rests on top of the woman's right hand. This girl's head is down and also rests in the woman's lap in an apparent expression of sorrow or grief. The figure on the right mirrors this position. Her left hand rests on or holds the woman's left hand.

A male figure sits on the right in a chair and faces left. He is Jack, a sailor, and the father of the two children near him. He wears a coat, pants, shoes, and a scarf at his neck. His hair (or wig?) is short and curly above his forehead and at the back of his neck. His left arm, and probably his right, are bent and rest in his lap. He may be holding his hands together. His crutch rests on the floor beneath his left foot.

A child, probably female, stands behind and to the left of the seated adult male. She is wearing a hat or cap, has her head down, and holds a scarf or cloth to her face. Her posture suggests sorrow or grief. The figure appears to be standing, but her legs are not pictured.

A male child stands to the right of the seated male figure. He may be leaning against the back of the chair. He has short curly hair and his eyes are cast down. His arms are crossed in front of his chest, with his left hand holding or resting on his right shoulder. His legs are crossed at the ankles. He may be wearing tights or a shirt and breeches. His posture suggests melancholy or grief.
The two adult figures in the scene are seated on chairs. The leftmost child in the design sits on a stool.
There is a fireplace in the center of the design. A fire burns on a small stack of wood kindling and smoke rises up the chimney.
Two model ships sit on a mantel above the fireplace. The ship on the right has sails. Four objects, possibly candlesticks (as in the engraving), stand between the two ships.
Two framed pictures hang to the left and right of the fireplace mantel.
The man's crutch rests on the floor below his left foot.
The scene is set in a room with beams supporting the roof.

desc.objtitle: The Ruined House: 'Be Calm, My Child,' for Plate 4, Object 8 (Butlin 244.8)

objnote.p: The design was engraved as plate 4 in the book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An adult female (Mrs. Mason) walks with two female children (Mary and Caroline). The woman is seen from behind and walks away from the viewer, with her head turned in profile to the left and slightly down. She is gowned and wears a cloak or shawl around her shoulders; she also wears a large hat with a bow, and her long hair cascades out from under a bonnet or hair net. Her arms are at her side and are slightly bent at the elbows. With her left arm, she embraces or holds the child to the left; though not pictured, she may hold hands with the child to the right. A female child stands to the right of the central figure. She is gowned and wears a hat. Her head is turned to the right, away from the other figures. She may be looking at something not pictured. Part of her body is hidden by the central figure; her left arm is bent and she may hold the right hand of the central figure. A second female child stands or walks to the left of the central figure. She is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer. She is gowned and wears a hat. Her right arm is extended at 45 degrees and touches the left leg of the central figure. On the left of the design stands a ruined house. The structure has two distinct windows and what might be a pilaster at its right corner. The structure appears broken, particularly above the highest window. Extending to the right is a wall or fence that is partially hidden by the figures and tree trunks. A lake or stream is pictured to the left and right of the group of figures, below the ruined building. Clumps of indeterminate vegetation, possibly water lilies, are pictured in the lake or stream lower left. Several trees with leaves and crossing trunks are pictured near the group of figures. Dark wash right of the ruined building may indicate a distant forest of trees or other vegetation. Washes in the sky suggest clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A central adult female (Mrs. Mason) walks with two children, Mary and Caroline. The woman is seen from behind and walks away from the viewer, with her head turned in profile to the left and slightly down. She is gowned and wears a cloak or shawl around her shoulders; she also wears a large hat with a bow, and her long hair cascades out from under a bonnet or hair net. Her arms are at her side and are slightly bent at the elbows. With her left arm, she embraces or holds the child to the left; though not pictured, she may hold hands with the child to the right.

A female child (Mary or Caroline) stands to the right of the central figure. She is gowned and wears a hat. Her body faces forward with her head turned to the right, away from the other figures. She may be looking at something not pictured. Her mouth may be slightly open. Part of her body is hidden by the central figure; her right arm is bent and she may hold the left hand of the central figure.

A female child (Mary or Caroline) stands or walks to the left of the central figure. She is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer; her hair is long. She is gowned and wears a hat. Her right arm is extended at 45 degrees and touches the left leg of the central figure.

On the left of the design stands a ruined house. The structure has two distinct windows and what may be a pilaster at its right corner. The structure appears broken, particularly above the highest window. Extending to the right is a wall or fence that is partially hidden by the figures and tree trunks.
A lake or stream is pictured in the middle distance to the left and right of the group of figures.
Clumps of indeterminate vegetation, possibly water lilies, are pictured in the lake or river.

Several trees with leaves and crossing or intertwined trunks appear on either bank of the lake or stream. They may represent willows. Dark wash to the right of the ruined house may indicate more distant trees.
The wash at the top of the design suggests a sky with clouds.

desc.objtitle: 'Œconomy and Self-Denial are Necessary,' for Plate 6, Object 9 (Butlin 244.9)

objnote.p: There is a repaired tear in the drawing, upper right. The design was engraved as plate 6 in the book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Mrs. Mason and her two charges, Mary and Caroline, visit a poor family. Eight figures are pictured in a small room with a door, a fireplace with a grate (but no fire). We can also see the inside of the roof with two supporting beams. On the left of the design, an adult female (Mrs. Mason) stands between two female children (Mary and Caroline). She is gowned and wears a hat. She may be listening to the woman to the right. She appears to be looking at the crouched figures in the lower half of the design with an expression of pity. She holds the hands of the children to her left and right. The children are both gowned and wear hats. The child on the left bends her left arm and holds the hand of the adult woman; the girl's right arm is down and the fingers of her right hand are slightly spread. The child on the right is partially obscured. She may hold hands (her right?) with the adult woman; her left arm is bent across her body. Both children look towards the other figures in the scene with expressions suggesting pity or surprise. Another female figure stands to the right of the doorway; she is the mother of the poor family that Mrs. Mason and her charges are visiting. She is gowned and wears a tattered hat with a bonnet or cloth underneath. She faces forward, but her head is turned in profile to the left. Her mouth is open and she may be speaking to Mrs. Mason. She holds an indistinct shape in her crossed arms; in the engraving this is more clearly an infant, seen from behind. An adult male figure, the father, sits in a chair facing right in the lower half of the design. He wears shoes, stockings(?), breeches, and a shirt. His hair is short and curly. His right arm rests on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left arm is bent and supports his head, which is bent down. His eyes are closed, and he wears an expression of despair, melancholy, or grief. To the right of the seated figure, a male child sits in an extremely contracted position and leans with his shoulder against the wall. He is facing forward, with his head turned slightly to the right. The figure appears to wear breeches. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His left arm is seen at his side. The child's eyes may be closed. The rightmost figure in this design is a male child seated on the floor with his back against the wall. He wears shoes, breeches, and a shirt or coat. He faces to the left, with his legs extended together. His left arm is at his side with his palm down. His head is bent down, and he wears a rather blank expression.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left of the design, an adult female (Mrs. Mason) stands between two female children. She is gowned and wears a hat; her long hair cascades onto her shoulders. Her right shoe is pictured. She faces forward with her head turned slightly to the right. She may be listening to the woman to the right. She appears to be looking at the crouched figures in the lower half of the design with an expression of pity. She holds the hands of the children to her left and right.

Two female children, Mary and Caroline, flank the adult woman standing on the left of the design. Both are gowned, have long hair, and wear hats. The child on the left holds the adult's hand with her left hand; her right arm is down with her fingers spread. We see her left shoe and perhaps a bit of her right shoe. The child on the right is partially obscured. She may hold hands (with her right hand?) with the adult woman; her left arm is bent across her body. Both children look towards the other figures in the scene with expressions suggesting pity. The expression of the girl on the left also suggests surprise.

A female figure, the mother of the family visited by Mrs. Mason and her charges, stands to the right of the doorway. She is gowned and wears a tattered hat with a bonnet, cloth, or scarf underneath covering her hair. She faces forward, but her head is turned in profile to the left. Her mouth is open and she may be speaking to Mrs. Mason. She holds an indistinct shape in her crossed arms; in the engraving this is more clearly an infant, seen from behind. Only the infant's head is clearly pictured.

A male figure, the father of the poor family, sits in a chair in the lower half of the design. He faces right and wears shoes, stockings(?), breeches, and a shirt. His hair is short and curly; he may have a short, stubble beard. His right arm rests on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left arm is bent and supports his head, which is bent down. His eyes are closed, and he wears an expression of despair, melancholy, or grief.
The adult male in the lower half of the design sits in a chair.

To the right of the seated figure, a male(?) child sits in an extremely contracted position and leans with his shoulder against the wall. The figure appears to wear breeches. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles; his right foot is bare. His left arm is shown at his side. The child's eyes are closed and he wears an expression of despair or grief.

The rightmost figure in this design is a male child seated on the floor with his back against a wall. He wears shoes, breeches, and a shirt. He faces to the left, with his legs extended together. His left arm is at his side with his palm down upon the floor. His head is bent down, and he wears a blank expression.

The scene is set in a small room with a doorway to the left on the back wall, a fireplace in the wall on the right, and a grate (but no fire) in the fireplace. We can also see the inside of the roof with supporting beams.

desc.objtitle: A Starving Woman with Two Children, Object 10 (Butlin 244.10)

objnote.p: This drawing was not selected as one of the six to be engraved.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The left half of the design depicts a starving woman and two children. They are apparently pictured in a room, possibly with a door on the left. The woman is gowned and wears a bonnet or cap and buckle shoes. She faces forward with her head up and an expression of grief or despair on her face. The woman's arms are bent upward and she holds a cloth in front of her chest with both hands. A male child with curly hair stands to the woman's left. He faces right and holds both arms vertically, reaching upward and holding (or at least touching) the woman's gown. A female child stands to the right of the woman, facing left. Her long hair may be drawn back in a loose braid. Her left arm is bent upward and she holds the woman's skirt. The right half of the design is a pencil sketch. A woman (Mrs. Mason) wears a large hat and faces left. Two female children (Mary and Caroline) stand near Mrs. Mason. The figure closest to the viewer (below Mrs. Mason) wears a hat and faces left. The figure to the left reaches to the right with her bent right arm. The two girls may be looking at each other. All three figures in this sketch are gowned.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left of the design, an old(?) emaciated female stands facing forward. She is gowned and wears a bonnet or cap and buckle shoes. The woman's arms are bent upward and she holds a cloth in front of her chest with both hands. Her mouth is open and she wears an expression of grief or despair. She may be speaking or crying.

A male child with curly hair stands to the left of the woman, facing right with his head turned up towards her. He wears breeches and a shirt. Both arms are raised vertically; he reaches upward and he holds (or at least touches) the skirt of the woman's gown with both hands.

A gowned female child stands to the right of the woman, facing left. She has long hair that may be drawn back into a loose braid. Her left arm is bent upward and she holds the skirt of the woman's gown with her left hand.
The figures on the left apparently stand in a room, possibly with a door on the left.
A gowned female figure (Mrs. Mason) stands to the right of the starving woman and children. She wears a large hat and faces to the left.

Two young gowned females (Mary and Caroline) stand to either side of Mrs. Mason. The figure on the right wears a hat and faces left. The figure to the left, apparently facing right, has her right arm extended and slightly bent. The girls may be looking at each other.
